@y6Qe5BN3: it’s not a shrinking or expansion of the economy we should be looking at. We should be looking at a complete overhaul of our environment, its resources and our position in it. For too long we have looked at the world and its resources as if they were our exclusive domain, to be used and abused as we see fit without regard for any negative repercussions. Take economic growth, for example. If we managed to grow at 4% per annum continuously, our economy would have doubled in size in 17 years and 4 months. That’s double the amount of resources required to sustain that level of economic activity by May 2037. We are living in a giant pyramid scheme and it’s rapidly approaching its end point. Either we manage its transformation starting now, or it will implode.

@kevin mc cormack:
A Free Trade Agreement: a new economic and social partnership with the United Kingdom
The agreement covers not just trade in goods and services, but also a broad range of other areas in the EU’s interest, such as investment, competition, State aid, tax transparency, air and road transport, energy and sustainability, fisheries, data protection, and social security coordination.
It provides for zero tariffs and zero quotas on all goods that comply with the appropriate rules of origin.
Both parties have committed to ensuring a robust level playing field by maintaining high levels of protection in areas such as environmental protection, the fight against climate change and carbon pricing, social and labour rights, tax transparency and State aid, with effective, domestic enforcement, a binding dispute settlement mechanism and the possibility for both parties to take remedial measures.
https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_2531
@On the right side: Don’t confuse Kevin with too many facts or he will become disoriented and not find his way to bed.

- “There will be also be an ‘adjustment period’ which provide stable access for 5 ½ years.”
This is the crucial clause, since there is no way the EU will permit indefinte tariff-free access without protecting the internal market, including free movement.
So Johnson can sell this as a major victory which is what it looks like, but in fact he bought himself the extension he was going to rule out.

To be fair: it isn’t an extension in the sense that this 5 ½ year period will give the British the political reality that they apparently need. It gives Johnson what he needs to politically survive. But come 2026 and we’ll be back where we started. The EU’s calculation is probably that by then, there will be another PM.
@Mick Tobin: The EU has plenty of such FTA agreements. Two are even up for ratification now, Canada and Mercosur (South America). What the UK wanted was Single Market membership without the rules.

For N Ireland the pandemic has been a gamechanger of a fundamental character.
Prior to March the arguments for it’s continuation, expressed here by Mr Wilson, had an historic validity within the Unionist and British establishment (obviously opposed within Nationalism).
The last six months have swept any such considerations aside, both in Brussels and in London.
A land border with a non-EU country with such a threat hanging out there for the Commission is a nonsense, Whitehall agrees, and wants the problem to go away.
Mr Wilson knows this and is just engaged in bluster before the inevitable realignment of the territory as an EU protectorate comes to pass.
The direct return of the territory to the Republic is probably still a step too far at this stage.

I have been reading some of the comments on here,and they are coming straight from the UKIP/Brexit Party lexicon. “The 4th Reich, EU Tyrants, Putting it up to the EU, EU bullies. It’s as if Farage himself were typing these comments.
The truth is while Brexit will be painful for us, it will prove disastrous for the UK.
Let’s look at it logically and by sector. Agriculture/Food: The vast majority of British Farmers have depended on EU subsidies to survive. They are now gone and the UK government version ends in 2022. This will see most either go to the wall or struggle badly. Added to this the UK currently can only produce 58% of its own basic food requirements. With farms going bust when the subsidies stop that percentage will drop dramatically. Which in turn will mean even more basic foods have to be imported at higher prices due to tariffs. It will also have a knock on effect on the UK food processing industries. Higher costs means less competitive, which in turn means cuts will be made and that usually means lay off’s.
Manufacturing: One of the UK’s most important manufacturing sector is the Auto sector. With 12% Tariffs on every car exported to the EU, it will become unsustainable for any of the large manufacturers to compete with their continental rivals. So the likes of Nissan Land Rover etc will relocate into the EU. But the UK jobs won’t follow because the UK have abandoned freedom of movement. And the loss of these companies will have a knock on effect on all their suppliers.
Shipping: With that UK’s need to import more and more, congestion at UK ports becomes a problem, this is not just a trucking problem, but one for shipping too. With the extra Customs documentation, Ferries and and container ships will be required to spend longer in port before being unloaded, which in turn will cause delays for arriving ships to hearth, and the delays land side mean trucks are delayed being loaded. Time is money and time wasted is going to cost that much more.
Services Sector: As we have seen over the past few years the exodus of Financial Institutions from the UK has been a steady flow, with s no deal Brexit that will become a flood. And again those Jobs won’t travel. The UK travel sector will also suffer. How many Brits will seek holiday and pay for visas for their annual trip to Spanish beaches? No more visa free travel is a double edged sword they never thought about.
And the list goes on. The UK will be feeling the negitive effects of Brexit for the next 20 years at a minimum.

@Mick.: Have you actually looked what the UK government is doing for UK farmers? They are going to be paid for land management regardless of what they chose to do with the land, they will be able to grow what they want in the quantities that they want & do it with technology if they so wish. How many financial institution have left the UK? The last thing I saw on Bloomberg was Deutsche Bank moving into a huge new London HQ & up until January of this year over a thousand EU financial institutions had plans to set up a new base in the UK, just google the Reuters story they don’t have any reason to tell porkies.

Will be interesting to see what comes out this week on the deal. It’s probably the best result economically for Ireland and NI. But allowing the UK to stay in the single market – what does that say about future dissent among countries who don’t like the EU taking control over more and more domestic policy areas. If a France or Germany decided next year it wants free trade but not all the other stuff, it’d be end of the EU. And there’s precedent there for an exit now. The far-right in Europe and the likes of Farage will sell this as a UK win. Which will suit the US, China, Russia. A unified EU has major clout; individual countries not much. Either way, I hope Boris enjoys his fish fingers.

@RogersRabbit: They’re not in the single market, they have a trade deal for goods that is by no means frictionless but it doesn’t cover their services market that is about 80% of their economy and 50% of export. The reason it isn’t frictionless is precisely why Northern Ireland will de facto stay in the single market, and the reason why the EU refused the British to solve the border question via the trade deal. It would have given them way too much, and opened the door to the sort of trouble potentially that you’re describing above. We’ll still have to see how it all plays out but this seems pretty much the best that could be achieved politically. And it’s via the services market that the EU retains a good deal of leverage on the British.
@RogersRabbit: very difficult for eurozone members to leave the EU. Would need to move to a new currency and would risk capital flight.

I would recommend book by Douglas Murray -The Strange Death of Europe is the internationally bestselling account of a continent and a culture caught in the act of suicide. These include rapid changes in the dynamics of global politics, world leadership and terror attacks across Europe.
Douglas Murray travels across Europe to examine first-hand how mass immigration, cultivated self-distrust and delusion have contributed to a continent in the grips of its own demise. From the shores of Lampedusa to migrant camps in Greece, from Cologne to London, he looks critically at the factors that have come together to make Europeans unable to argue for themselves and incapable of resisting their alteration as a society. Murray’s “tremendous and shattering” book addresses the disappointing failures of multiculturalism, Angela Merkel’s U-turn on migration, the lack of repatriation and the Western fixation on guilt, uncovering the malaise at the very heart of the European culture. His conclusion is bleak, but the predictions not irrevocable. As Murray argues, this may be our last chance to change the outcome, before it’s too late.

@Anthony Connor: You’re incorrect. The EAW is an EU legal instrument. It is by far the best and most robust legal instrument and has worked very well. The legal instruments universally used prior to this, including with the U.K., were incredibly cumbersome and inherently political. Extraditions were routinely blocked on political and technical grounds. Now that the U.K. is proposing to diverge from mainstream European legal norms including the ECHR, extradition could again become highly political issue and legally problematic. Shared membership of the EU allowed these issues to be thrashed out and resolved. But the U.K. is now becoming a third country and the mutterings of senior U.K. political figures would indicate that they want the independence of their courts to be curtailed.

German unification was a disaster and not only a financial one. Kohl’s only strategy was how to use unification to win the general election. Anyone, who suggested a transitional approach was jeered at and labelled “unpatriotic”. Indeed there are many similarities to Brexit – a romantic notion with plenty of spin but zero plan.
Other countries such as Slovenia, which escaped the schackels of communism at the same time, attracted inward investment, example by reducing corporate taxes. One of the greatest impediments is the currency.
At present N Ireland is nominally a Sterling jurisdiction, although the actual currency notes used there are not recognised in England, Scotland or Wales.
Practically everywhere in N Ireland gives an exchange rate for Euro.
If the UK government and the EU agree to change the denomination of the N Ireland currency to Euro, charging for goods and services in Euro whilst giving an exchange rate for Sterling, it would do a lot to ease the eventual reunification when agreement is reached on other political and social issues.

@Garry Coll:
You’re not entirely correct there.
I’ve used NI Stirling many times in England, Scotland and Wales. Sure you get the occasional look of confusion when you pass over a note but that’s only because not many cashiers see them too often.
Retailers are not obliged to accept NI notes but all banks do. It depends on how the retailer does their banking.

Gove is conveniently forgetting the new complex arrangement with Northern Ireland to replace the backstop. Under the backstop there would be a shared legal framework with the EU to keep the border open, but Johnson wanted this to be solely under UK law. The proposed patchwork to keep the so-called union intact will come at a price, and that price is a trade deal that will be even harder to finalise. After all, however presented, there will be a de facto open border between the UK and the EU’s common market, and the EU will want to ensure the integrity of that market. This has inevitable consequences for the free movement of people (the immigration that Brexit was always about) and for the UK’s ability to strike its own trade deals with the rest of the world. This will take years and years to sort out.

Very badly written article. No member of the EU switches their clocks back to GMT at the end of October. The article states all 27 do, despite the fact that there are three different offsets operating in metropolitan EU (i.e excluding the likes of French Guiane). The only country that did switch back to GMT – the UK – is gone. Ireland, which operates on the same offset as the UK currently, switches to WET, or Western European Time in October, with Irish Standard Time operating during the summer. We do not operate GMT here at any time during the year. Our timezone and offset is simply coincidental to the UK’s. GMT is legally set by the Westminster parliament. IST is legally set by the Dáil.
@Brian Ó Dálaigh: And as well as that the article says end of March to end of October, yet a few sentences later says summertime lasts for six months of the year. Someone’s not with it today.

@Brian Ó Dálaigh: We operate on Greenwich Mean Time in winter. It’s specified as such in the Statute Book.
http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1971/act/17/enacted/en/print

Such a border poll would not be forcing anyone into a united Ireland, as the outcome would not be predetermined and unionists would be part of that decision process/outcome.
On the contrary – the longer Irish politicians in the south keeps putting off that democratic poll – they are in effect predetermining that a united Ireland can’t happen. 100 years after partition was put in place, southern politicians need to understand that Unionism by its very nature wont/cant change by its own volition, that’s why they are unionists. @Paul O Faolain: there is a border as anyone and everyone should know. There are borders to all of the 32 counties in Ireland – you can even know when crossing such a border as the road surface may change (e.g. driving from Dublin to Blessington). There are also Provence borders … but of course you are referring to the border between the part of Ireland under the jurisdiction of the Republic and the part under the juristiction of the UK.
Believe it or not some people actually need a passport and a visa to cross that border as people with in the UK including Northern Ireland cannot cross that border without an Irish Visa if an Irish visa is required. Likewise people in the Republic cannot cross the border into Northern Ireland without a UK visa if a UK visa is needed. And people with an Irish and UK holiday visa must have a multi entrance visa to cross the border. The one exception is I believe for Chinese nationals who can obtain a common visa for both the UK and Ireland. There are a few other exceptions – but yes there is a political and immigration border on the island of Ireland.
http://www.inis.gov.ie/en/INIS/Pages/Will%20an%20Irish%20visa%20allow%20me%20to%20travel%20to%20Northern%20Ireland
This is the reason that some people in Donegal must travel via Sligo to visit Dublin – the common travel area only covers UK and Irish passport holders.

File image of the Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney.
File image of the Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney.
Image: PA
UK breaching Northern Ireland Protocol would be a ‘really big mistake’, Coveney says
The British government is poised to reintroduce elements of its controversial Internal Market Bill next week,
12 hours ago 15,585 35
THE FOREIGN AFFAIRS Minister Simon Coveney has warned the UK it will be making “a really big mistake” if it breaches the Northern Ireland Protocol on Brexit.
The British government is poised to reintroduce elements of its controversial Internal Market Bill next week, which could override the protocol, in a move that would breach international law.
It is also set to table its finance bill, elements of which could also breach parts of the Northern Ireland Protocol – designed to prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland – agreed last year.
It comes amid an intense period of negotiations between the EU and the UK to reach a post-Brexit trade deal.
Coveney said today that such a move by the UK would be taken as a “clear signal” by the EU that the UK does not want a deal.
ADVERTISEMENT
He said: “I think if they do that, it will be a clear signal to the EU that this process is not going to conclude well.
It will be a signal that they effectively don’t want a deal. I really hope that doesn’t happen.
“We have certainly given signals in as respectful, but in as blunt a way as we can, that that would be a really big mistake at this stage in negotiations.
“I think Michel Barnier’s briefing of the meeting this morning would reflect that too.”
Earlier today, the EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier reportedly briefed European ambassadors that a breach of the Northern Ireland Protocol would trigger a “crisis” and cause a breakdown in trust.
Coveney told the Oireachtas Committee on the Withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union today that an agreement on the implementation of the protocol is close.
He expressed his hope that a deal will be reached soon, which could negate the need for the UK to introduce its own domestic legislation which could override the protocol.
He said: “There’s a lot of negotiating to happen between now and then. I hope there will be no need for domestic legislation that threatens the implementation of the protocol, because of a successful outcome to negotiation. Time will tell.”
#OPEN JOURNALISM No news is bad news Support The Journal Your contributions will help us continue to deliver the stories that are important to you
SUPPORT US NOW
Coveney was heavily critical of the British government’s actions around the Internal Market Bill, which he said had damaged their reputation internationally.
He said: “We’ve wasted so much time talking about the Internal Market Bill. The motivation of the British Government in terms of why they’re doing it.
Is it a negotiating strategy? Is it a way of potentially sinking these negotiations if they wanted to?
Coveney added: “It’s undoubtedly doing damage to Britain’s reputation internationally. Not just in the European Union, on the other side of the Atlantic as well.
“They’re just trying to understand, what is the British Government at here?
“It’s in some ways a very provocative approach that has undermined trust and sucked in a huge amount of oxygen that could have been used to resolve these issues through negotiation.
We could have a second piece of legislation that doubles down on the issue through the Finance Bill next week, in the context of another element of the protocol.
“I think the EU will draw only one conclusion if that course of action happens, which will be hugely regrettable.”

When people get past the idea of UK government being in breach of an International Treaty, and look at the details of what they want to change, it all makes sense. Clearly the UKG doesn’t want to be bound by the State Aid/Level Playing Field rules being forced on them by the EU. The NI Protocol has a trojan horse clause that would undermine this UKG LPF stance. The other two issues concern the protocols for checking cargo East/West and West/East between NI and GB. Hardly a showstopping issue for Ireland, or the threat to the GFA. The smart move for Ireland and EU is to get past all this hyperbole, sit down with the UK in good faith and cut a deal that does NOT hold the UKG over an LPF barrel.

Leo Varadkar was visiting County Offaly primary school and the class was in the middle of a discussion about words and their meanings.
The teacher asked Mr. Varadkar if he would like to lead the discussion on the word ‘Tragedy’.
So Mr. Varadkar asked the class if they could think of an example of a tragedy?
A little boy stood up and said, ‘If a man walks out in front of a bus and is killed stone dead, then that is a tragedy.”
‘Incorrect,’ said Leo ‘That would merely be an accident.’
A little girl stood up and said ‘If a school bus carrying thirty children drove over a cliff, killing everybody inside, that would be a tragedy.’
‘I’m afraid not’, said Leo, ‘That’s what we would call a great loss’.
The room went silent. No other kid volunteered. Leo searched the room.
‘Isn’t there someone here who can give me an example of a tragedy?’
Finally, little Johnny raised his hand from the back of the class and said, ‘If a plane carrying you and all the Fine Gael, Fianna Fáil and Labour T.D.s was hit by a missile and blown to smithereens, that would be a tragedy.’
‘Fantastic!’ exclaimed Leo. ‘And can you tell me why that would be a tragedy?’
‘Well,’ said little Johnny, ‘It has to be a tragedy, because it certainly wouldn’t be a great loss, and it probably wouldn’t be a ffff.. g accident either’ ;)

What Brexit supporters are either ignoring, forgetting or simple don’t understand is that the UK will still have to import the same goods from the EU, if they wish to continue with the lifestyle they currently enjoy. It will just cost them more.
The UK is only 58% self sufficient in food production. 38% of the remaining food requirements currently come from the EU. The majority of components and raw materials it’s industrial base require, come from the EU. And the finished products are exported to the EU.
With higher prices for practically everything in the UK, the demand for higher wages will follow, which in turn will push up prices even more as companies struggle to maintain profit margins.
Some of those who can, may relocate back into the EU, leaving workers stranded in the UK, as UK workers will have no automatic right to employment within the EU.
Inflation will begin to spiral because of higher prices and following wage demands, unemployment will grow as companies find they cant compete with their EU rivals and go bust, down size or relocate.
The UK are looking at a minimum of two decades of austerity before they can recover from a No Deal Brexit.
Brexiteers will try argue the the UK is the 5th largest economy. But again ignore the fact that it was because of EU membership not in spite of it. And now they are out, they will find the international markets to be a cold and hostile place.

Deffo – an industry that literally eats into its base.

There is fishing and then there is fishing. Successive governments (especially Fianna Fail) have been good friends to the owners of super trawlers who produce a large quantity of poor quality fish. On the other hand, the State has systematically shafted inshore fishing, which is far more sustainable, largely because local fishermen are fishing local stocks.
At the same time Ireland has encouraged the almost unregulated development of salmon farming. This is a horribly polluting industry, that destroys wild population of salmon and sea trout,and at the same time destroys the stock of small fish that sea trout, especially, depend upon.

As a consumer we can help:
- never buy farmed salmon, it is worse than chlorinated chicken! Alaskan Pacific salmon is wild fish from a tightly regulated scientifically managed fishery, you can eat that with a clear conscience.
- source fish from local fishermen or buy fish labelled as being from sustainable fisheries.
- don’t eat species of fish that are threatened: cod, seabass, salmon. There are many more fish species that are delicious.
- catch your own. Anglers are the best defense against polluters, poachers and the politicians who aid and abet them. Teach your children to fish.
- avoid all farmed fish… until they are.produced on land in fully enclosed systems.
Declaration of interest: I adore eating fish and she’ll fish, and I am a.passionate angler.

https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/consumer/shopping/buying_online_from_uk_after_brexit.html
;How you will pay VAT and customs charges’
There are two ways VAT and customs charges are applied to eligible purchases from the UK:
The business can register with Revenue and collect Irish VAT and any duties payable when you are making your purchase online. You should not have to pay any UK VAT on your purchase. You will not have to pay further Revenue charges on delivery.
If the business is not registered with Revenue, then your package may be subject to VAT and other charges on arrival into Ireland from the UK. The postal service or courier company delivering the package will complete the relevant customs declarations, including where the product is manufactured. You will get a bill from the courier or postal company before your package is delivered. The company usually have an administration charge. Charges vary and there may be a minimum charge (between €10 to €15).

@Andre le Flohic: Splitting hairs – but it is OK to call an English man British just as it is OK to call a Cork man Irish.
The sovereign state is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and the government is often referred to as the British Government just as the army is referred to as the British Army.
People born in the UK or of UK parents are entitled to be considered British and, in the case of Boris Johnson, I am sure he holds a British password.
There is no current sovereign state called England, or Wales or Scotland or Northern Ireland, they are all part of the UK (inc. NI) and the term British is the correct one internationally just as “Irish” people include internal subdivisions from Cork to Donegal, “British” people include those citizens of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, the British Overseas Territories, and the Crown dependencies.
So internationally there is no real thing called England at this time (except for sports when it suits them soccer and rugby but not olympics – it is great to be able to pick and choose)… and Boris is British and head on the British government and holds a British passpor.

@Lee Kelly (he/him): so it looks like Boris is using ‘level playing field’ to get a better fisheries deal (larger area to fish in? Effecting Ireland?) Can anyone explain what the ‘level playing field’ agreement is?

@Lad: In very brief terms the “level playing field” is a “set of common rules and standards that prevent businesses in one country gaining a competitive advantage over those operating in other countries.”
This ruleset is only applicable if you want to be a full member of the European Single Market and it essentially eliminates tariffs on *all* goods and services because you have have agreed to operate within that common framework and incorporates what we now consider to be the standard EU philosophy as regards the free movement of people as well as commercial goods.
The alternative would be a standard trade agreement whereby each side waives tariffs on certain goods you want to export in exchange for reciprocity on other goods they want to export.
In essence, if the UK actually want to remain in the ESM, they have to match the terms already agreed by the 31 member participants. That’s the “level playing field” in a nutshell.

While it’s easy to sneer at Boris and Brexit, the reality is that the GFA makes N Ireland a valuable bargaining chip for the UK in its negotiations with the EU.
After the DUP’s humiliation of Mrs May at the EU leaders summit several years ago, the Conservatives appeared to have had enough and don’t want to be held hostage by them again.
This move seems to be a way for Boris to offload that millstone, and at the same time find out how much the EU is willing to pay to buy the UK out of the GFA.
The obvious benefit for the EU is that if it does take control of N Ireland, it gets rid of the land border between the territories once and for all.
Maybe Boris has some new found affection for the six counties, but he has always seemed to work more through pragmatism than emotion.

While a no deal Brexit will undoubtedly be painful for Ireland, it is going to be an unmitigated disaster for the UK.
Where we will have the, financial, economic and political support of 26 other nations to aid in our recovery, the UK will be out in the cold, on its own, a small Island in the North Atlantic.
It will still have to import the same as it currently does, that won’t change, it will just cost a lot more.

It’s not about the fish lads – except in terms of what they call ‘optics’ in politics. It’s all about the level playing field. It’s about the EU not accepting a country on its doorstep that undercuts competition by giving state aid.
So this is what’ll happen: the EU will make concessions about the fish, which makes up a tiny percentage of the economy, and the UK will make concessions about the level playing field, which is about major parts of both economies.
And the result is that Boris Johnson will be able to say something like this: “We’ve taken back control of our waters, and of our borders, and we’ve ended free movement.” So he’ll be able to sell the resulting wafer-thin deal to his base.
But in reality the UK will be significantly subject to EU free market rules, and the deal Boris will be able to sell by aforementioned optics won’t be a free-trade deal by a long shot, since there’s no free movement, so there’ll be tariffs.
But that’s not the point. The point is that a deal, however thin, that can be sold to the electorate.

@PaulOMahoney Irish: just to be clear, trade deal or no trade deal, there are going to be customs formalities to be taken care of. On export from Ireland to the UK an export declaration has to be submitted before the carrier gets permission to put his truck or container on a ferry or container ship. The export declaration also has a security part that has to be transmitted to the UK to approve the loading. That also applies in reverse. There is a lot of information available to assist importers and exporters in their preparation for Brexit. One major change is that VAT is going to be payable on submitting an import customs entry (and possibly duty in case of no deal)

London’s financial services are up for grabs (Britain lost services in the trade deal) and Dublin is one of the big four in Europe now – Frankfurt, Amsterdam, Luxembourg, and Dublin. Ireland has zero-tarriff/zero-quota access to the UK market for its produce/goods. The only loss is that Irish fishermen lose 25% of their catch, but there is a road around that and that is just registering fishing vessels in Northern Ireland. There is goodwill (for peace and prosperity) between the North and South generally speaking, so should work out well.

And where else are they going to get their fresh food and just-in-time supplies? And it’s not as if I, as an Irish consumer, can’t go ever so slightly further afield to get goods without the 5% that the UK would impose on their exports. And apparently tariffs are usually more like 10%.
We have the numbers and economic clout. And the UK are about to be our canary in the coalmine for a trade deal with the US. There is no way the US will give a better deal to the UK than to 450 million EU consumers.
